column1: Peter Rabbit was puzzled. He stared at Lightfoot the Deer a wee bit suspiciously. "Have you been tearing somebody's coat?" he asked again. He didn't like to think it of Lightfoot
column2: whom he always had believed quite as gentle
column4: and timid as himself. But what else could he think?Lightfoot slowly shook his head. "No
column5: said he, I haven't torn anybody's coat.""Then what are those rags hanging on your antlers?" demanded Peter.Lightfoot chuckled. "They are what is left of the coverings of my new antlers
column6: he explained.What's that? What do you mean by new antlers?" Peter was sitting up very straight
column7: with his eyes fixed on Lightfoot's antlers as though he never had seen them before."Just what I said
column8: retorted Lightfoot. What do you think of them? I think they are the finest antlers I've ever had. When I get the rest of those rags off
column9: they will be as handsome a set as ever was grown in the Green Forest."
